title: 112_hr6137
content: The Act titled "Helping Save Americans' Health Care Choices Act of 2012" is abbreviated as such and includes a table of sections. The "Helping Save Americans' Health Care Choices Act of 2012" includes sections on repealing taxes on distributions from HSAs and MSAs, deductions for non-prescription drugs, treatment of high deductible health plans, flexible spending arrangements, savers credit for HSA contributions, using HSA funds for premiums, and coordination between plan administrators. Sec. 9. Special rule for certain medical expenses incurred before establishment of account. Sec. 10. Provisions relating to medicare. Sec. 11. Individuals eligible for veterans benefits for a service-connected disability. Sec. 12. Increase the maximum contribution limit to an HSA to match deductible and out-of-pocket expense limitation. Sec. 13. FSA funds may be used for long-term care insurance premiums. Sec. 14. Individuals eligible for TRICARE. Sec. 15. Certain physician fees to be treated as medical care. Sec. 16. Allow both spouses to make catch-up contributions to the same HSA account. SEC. 2. REPEAL OF ADDITIONAL TAX FROM DISTRIBUTIONS FROM HSAS AND MSAS. Repeals Section 9004 of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, amending the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 3. REPEAL OF LIMITATION ON DEDUCTIONS MAKING NON-PRESCRIPTION DRUGS NON-QUALIFYING DISTRIBUTIONS FROM TAX-PREFERRED ACCOUNTS. Repeals Section 9003 of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, amending the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 4 amends the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act to treat high deductible health plans as qualified health plans. SEC. 5 repeals limitations on health flexible spending arrangements. SEC. 6 introduces a saver's credit for contributions to health savings accounts. SEC. 6 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow for aggregate qualified HSA contributions and defines qualified HSA contributions for tax deductions. The amendments made by this section apply to contributions made after December 31, 2012, reducing aggregate retirement savings and HSA contributions by distributions received during the testing period. HSA funds can be used for premiums for high deductible health plans. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows for premiums of high deductible health plans to be excluded from gross income under certain conditions. Premiums for high deductible health plans can be excluded from gross income for periods starting after December 31, 2012. SEC. 8. Encouraging coordination between high deductible health plan administrators and HSA account administrators for simultaneous enrollment. SEC. 9. Special rule for certain medical expenses incurred before account establishment. Treatment of health savings account established before tax return due for tax year: If a taxpayer establishes a health savings account, makes contributions, or makes payments/distributions before the tax return due date, the account is deemed established on the last day of the taxable year. The amendments made by this section apply to health savings accounts established, contributions, and distributions after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 10. PROVISIONS RELATING TO MEDICARE. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding Medicare eligibility and contributions for individuals over 65 and Medicare Advantage MSA beneficiaries. Effective date applies to taxable years after enactment. The effective date for the amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding Medicare eligibility and contributions applies to taxable years after the enactment of this Act. Individuals eligible for veterans benefits for a service-connected disability. Individuals eligible for certain veterans benefits for a service-connected disability are not considered covered under a health plan merely for receiving periodic hospital care or medical services for that disability. This rule applies if they are not eligible for such care or services for any other condition. The amendment is effective immediately. The amendment made by this section applies to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 12 increases the maximum contribution limit to an HSA to match deductible and out-of-pocket expense limitations for self-only and family coverage. The amendments apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 13 allows FSA funds to be used for long-term care insurance premiums. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exclude employer-provided coverage for qualified long-term care services through flexible spending arrangements from an employee's gross income. This amendment is effective from January 1, 2013. Qualified medical expenses for long-term care coverage can be reimbursed through a flexible spending arrangement. The amendment excludes employer-provided long-term care coverage from an employee's gross income. Effective for taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 14 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow individuals eligible for TRICARE to be considered eligible for certain tax benefits. The amendment applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 15 specifies that certain physician fees will be treated as medical care. SEC. 15 amends the Internal Revenue Code to include pre-paid physician fees as medical care. This amendment applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow for a special rule where both spouses are eligible individuals with 1 health savings account. If both spouses are over age 55 and only one has an account, the additional contribution amount will be 200 percent of the usual amount. This amendment applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act.
